metadata.title: Atomically thick Ni(OH)2 nanomeshes for urea electrooxidation

sections.heading: Nanoscale
sections.text:
PAPER
Cite this: Nanoscale, 2019, 11, 1058
Received 7th October 2018, Accepted 10th December 2018
DOI: 10.1039/c8nr08104b
rsc.li/nanoscale
Atomically thick Ni(OH)2 nanomeshes for urea electrooxidation
Yu Ding,†a Ying Li,†a Yuanyuan Xue,b Boqiang Miao,b Shuni Li, *a Yucheng Jiang, *a Xien Liu c and Yu Chen b
Atomically thick ultrathin nanomeshes (NMs) possessing the inherent advantages of both two-dimen-
sional nanomaterials and porous nanomaterials are attracting increasing interest in catalysis and electro-
catalysis. Herein, we report a direct chemical synthesis of atomically thick Ni(OH)2-NMs by a NaBH4 assisted cyanogel hydrolysis method, which overcomes the shortcoming of the post-etching method for
NM synthesis. Various physical characterization methods show that the as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs have 1.7 nm thickness, a big surface area, abundant nanoholes, and numerous surface/edge atoms with low-
coordination numbers. The as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs show a better electrocatalytic performance for the urea oxidation reaction than conventional Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles without holes in the alkaline electrolyte, including a lower onset oxidation potential, faster reaction kinetics, and higher mass activity.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Electrocatalysis occupies an extremely important place in the field of sustainable and environmentally friendly energy conversion. Limited by the high cost and rarity of precious metals, transition metal-based nanomaterials (TMBNMs) have attracted wide attention in electrocatalysis, and have become promising precious metal-alternative electrocatalysts for the nitrogen reduction reaction,1,2 carbon dioxide reduction reaction,3,4 oxygen evolution reaction,5–13 hydrogen evolution reaction,14–17 methanol oxidation reaction,18,19 urea oxidation reaction (UOR),20–26 and so on. Among various TMBNMs with different morphologies, two-dimensional (2D) TMBNMs with an atomic thickness are particularly attractive for electrocatalysis, and generally show a super electrocatalytic activity due to their larger surface area and numerous low-coordination surface atoms with high activity.27–34
Unfortunately, atomically thick 2D TMBNMs suffer from unreachable cross-plane reactant diffusion because of their ultrahigh sheet aspect ratio. Meanwhile, numerous investigations have demonstrated that atoms at edges are more active than atoms at basal planes for electrocatalysis.35,36 Thus, 2D
ultrathin TMBNMs with abundant nanoholes (i.e., nanomeshes, NMs) are expected to show a higher electrocatalytic activity compared to their counterparts without holes because the existence of numerous holes not only facilitates mass transportation, but also generates copious atoms at the edge with super electrocatalytic activity.37–52
At present, ultrathin transition metal NMs with an atomic thickness are generally achieved by etching ultrathin nanosheets with an acid,45,48,50 an alkali,39,49 plasma,45 NH3, 51 H2, 52 NaH2PO2, 53 and so on. Even now the direct one-step synthesis of atomically thick transition metal NMs is a significant challenge. In this work, we developed a simple NaBH4 assisted cyanogel hydrolysis strategy to directly prepare atomically thick 2D Ni(OH)2 nanomeshes. UOR (CO(NH2)2 + 6OH
− → N2 + 5H2O + CO2 + 6e
−), an important half-reaction for direct urea fuel cells and urea-assisted water splitting, suffers from sluggish kinetics due to complex six-electron transfer and the requirement for precious metal electrocatalysts.25,26 Fortunately, recent advanced studies have demonstrated that Ni-based nanomaterials have comparable electroactivity to precious metal nanomaterials for the UOR in an alkaline electrolyte. When using as an electrocatalyst for the UOR in 1 M KOH solution, herein, Ni(OH)2-NMs showed excellent electrocatalytic activity due to their high surface area, numerous edge active atoms, and fast mass transportation.

sections.heading: Synthesis of Ni(OH)2-NMs
sections.text:
In a typical synthesis, a blue and insoluble jelly-like NiCl2– K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel (Fig. 1a) with high water affinity was†These authors contributed equally to this work.

facilely obtained via a ligand-substitution reaction between NiCl2 and K2Ni(CN)4 at room temperature (Fig. 1b), and possessed particular 2D structural units in its molecular structure (Fig. 1b).54–56 After adding NaBH4 aqueous solution into the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel for 8 h, black Ni(OH)2-NMs were achieved by centrifugation. For comparison, Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles without nanoholes (termed Ni(OH)2-NPs) were prepared by taking NiCl2 as the Ni II source in the same way.

sections.heading: Characterization of Ni(OH)2-NMs
sections.text:
Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy was used to determine the composition of the as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs. EDX data reveal that the product contains Ni and O elements and the Ni/O atomic ratio is about 1 : 2 (Fig. 2a). Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) was performed to analyze the crystal structure of Ni(OH)2-NMs. Unfortunately, no identifiable diffraction peaks are observed in the PXRD pattern of the product (Fig. 2b), which implies that the obtained product has an amorphous structure. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was applied to probe the elemental and electronic information of Ni(OH)2-NMs. No B2p signal is observed, suggesting that the nickel-borate is nonexistent in Ni(OH)2-NMs. XPS analysis shows that the atomic ratio of Ni to O is about 1 : 2, which is
very close to EDX analysis. The Ni 2p XPS spectrum reveals a pair of Ni 2p3/2 (853.23 eV) and Ni 2p1/2 (870.85 eV) peaks accompanied by two shakeup satellites (Fig. 2c). The spinenergy separation between Ni 2p1/2 and Ni 2p3/2 (17.6 eV) is a typical characteristic of the β-Ni(OH)2 phase, indicating that the chemical composition of Ni(OH)2-NMs is β-Ni(OH)2. For the O 1s XPS spectrum, three peaks at 529.5 eV, 531.2 eV, and 532.8 eV can be identified (Fig. 2d), which correspond to O atoms in the Ni–O bond, O atoms in the vicinity of the O vacancy, and O atoms in the adsorbed water molecules, respectively.25,42,46 The clear O 1s peak at 531.2 eV indicates that numerous edge atoms exist in Ni(OH)2-NMs. 25,42,46
The primary morphological and structural properties of Ni(OH)2-NMs were visualized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As observed, Ni(OH)2-NMs present a lamellar structure and the yield of Ni(OH)2-NMs almost reaches 100% (Fig. 3a and b). Scanning TEM-EDX (STEM-EDX) mapping images show the existence of Ni and O elements and their uniform distribution in Ni(OH)2-NMs (Fig. 3c). The selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of Ni(OH)2-NMs lacks clear reflection dots (Fig. 3d), which indicates that Ni(OH)2-NMs have a weak crystallinity, consistent with the XRD result. The atomic force microscopy (AFM) image confirms the 2D structure of Ni(OH)2-NMs and the height profiles show that the thickness of Ni(OH)2-NMs is only ca. 1.7 nm (Fig. 3e), which is the thickness of ca. 3 unit cells of β-Ni(OH)2.
The microstructures of Ni(OH)2-NMs were further characterized by high resolution TEM (HR-TEM). The HR-TEM image displays that holes exist on nanosheets (Fig. 4a). A further
Fig. 1 (a) The photograph of the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel. (b) The reaction equation of the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel. (c) 2D structural unit in the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel.

magnified HR-TEM image reveals numerous nanoholes with ca. 1.2 nm diameter evenly existing on the nanosheet surface (Fig. 4b). Undoubtedly, the existence of abundant nanoholes is conducive to the reduction of substrate mass transportation resistance. To further confirm the existence of nanoholes, a nitrogen adsorption desorption isotherm experiment was also carried out. Ni(OH)2-NMs display a type-IV isotherm with a hysteresis loop (Fig. 4c), which is a typical characteristic of porous nanomaterials.57–60 The hole-size distribution curve also confirms that Ni(OH)2-NMs possess numerous nanoholes with 1.2 nm diameter (inset in Fig. 4c), which is coincident with HR-TEM observation. The specific surface area of the as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs is found to be 126.4 m 2 g−1 according to the corresponding isotherm. Obviously, the atomic thickness of Ni(OH)2-NMs contributes to such a high surface area. The magnified HR-TEM image reveals clear lattice fringes of 0.232 nm (Fig. 4d), which corresponds to the (101) facets of β-Ni(OH)2.

sections.heading: Formation mechanism of Ni(OH)2-NMs
sections.text:
So far, all physical characterization methods have demonstrated that atomically thick Ni(OH)2-NMs with a big surface area, abundant nanoholes, and numerous edge atoms have been achieved successfully by the NaBH4 assisted cyanogel hydrolysis method. In a control experiment, NiCl2 is used as a reaction precursor to synthesize Ni(OH)2 nanostructures under the same experimental conditions. Only random aggregated and irregular Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles without nanoholes (termed Ni(OH)2-NPs) are obtained (Fig. 5a–c), and their surface area is only 40.8 m2 g−1 (Fig. 5d). This fact suggests that the generation of the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel (Fig. 1a) plays a key role in the formation of atomically thick Ni(OH)2-
NMs. As shown in Fig. 1c, 2D structural units exist in the NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel, which can work as a 2D self-platform for the self-assembly of the crystal nucleus, resulting in
Fig. 4 (a) HR-TEM image, (b) magnified HR-TEM image, (c) nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm and (d) further magnified HR-TEM image of Ni(OH)2-NMs. Inset in (b): Histogram of aperture distribution of the pore size; inset in (c): hole-size distribution curve.

the generation of nanosheets. Meanwhile, Cl− and CN− ligands on 2D structural units naturally fall off during the generation of nanosheets. As a result, the intrinsic spatial volumes of Cl– and CN– ligands are released, which results in the generation of nanoholes.

sections.heading: UOR performance of Ni(OH)2-NMs
sections.text:
The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) technique was applied to evaluate the UOR activity of Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs. LSV curves show that both Ni(OH)2-NMs (Fig. 6a) and Ni(OH)2NPs (Fig. 6b) have obvious electrocatalytic activity for the UOR in KOH solution. As is observed, the anodic currents at both Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs obviously increase after adding urea (Fig. 6a and b), confirming their reactivity for the UOR. In the range of 1.3 to 1.8 V potential, the oxidation current of the UOR at Ni(OH)2-NMs is higher than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs. For example, at 1.45 and 1.55 V potential, UOR current values at Ni(OH)2-NMs are 154.8 and 417.6 mA mg
−1, which are 7.7 times and 10.6 times higher than those at Ni(OH)2-NPs, respectively (Fig. 6a and b). According to the double-layer capacitance method,61,62 the electrochemically active surface areas (ECSA) of Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs are found to be 111.43 m2 g−1 and 43.07 m2 g−1, respectively. ECSA normalized LSV
curves show that the oxidation current of the UOR at Ni(OH)2NMs is still higher than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs (Fig. 6c). This fact indicates that both the big ECSA value and high intrinsic activity of Ni(OH)2-NMs contribute to their high mass activity. Herein, a potential at 10 mA cm−2 current density was defined as the onset potential value of the UOR. The onset oxidation potentials of the UOR at Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs start at 1.35 V and 1.39 V, respectively. The lower UOR onset potential and bigger UOR current suggest that Ni(OH)2-NMs have significantly higher activity than Ni(OH)2-NPs. Since Ni III species are the active center for the UOR,23,26,63 we investigate the electrochemical properties of Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2NPs by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) technique (Fig. 6d). CV curves reveal that the formation potential of NiII to NiIII at Ni(OH)2-NMs is more negative than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs, which is responsible for the lower UOR onset potential at Ni(OH)2-NMs. Meanwhile, the oxidation peak area of Ni
II to NiIII at Ni(OH)2-NMs is much bigger than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs, indicating that Ni(OH)2-NMs can produce more Ni
III active species compared to Ni(OH)2-NPs at the same potential. Consequently, abundant NiIII active species on Ni(OH)2-NMs contribute to the UOR activity enhancement.
The UOR kinetics at Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs were analyzed by plotting the Tafel slope (Fig. 6e). The Tafel slope values of 80 and 231 mV dec−1 are achieved at Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs, respectively. Since a smaller Tafel slope value stands for a higher UOR reactivity, the present Tafel slope values suggest that the UOR kinetics at Ni(OH)2-NMs is faster than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs. CV measurements have revealed that Ni(OH)2-NMs contain more Ni
III active species than Ni(OH)2-NPs, which accelerates the UOR kinetics. The charge-transfer rates of the UOR at Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2NPs were investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements (Fig. 6f). Generally, a smaller charge transfer resistance (Rct) value stands for a faster charge transfer rate. The Rct values at Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs are ca. 86.0 Ω and 698.1 Ω, respectively, indicating that the charge transfer rate of the UOR at Ni(OH)2-NMs is much faster than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs. 22 The abundant NiIII active species
Fig. 7 (a) LSV curves of Ni(OH)2-NMs, commercial Pt black electrocatalyst, and RuO2 nanoparticles in N2-saturated 1 M KOH solution with 0.33 M urea at a scan rate of 50 mV s−1. The commercial Pt black electrocatalyst and RuO2 nanoparticles were obtained from Johnson Matthey Corporation and Aladdin Industrial Corporation, respectively. (b) Chronoamperometry curves of Ni(OH)2-NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs in N2saturated 1 M KOH solution with 0.33 M urea at 1.48 V potential.

are favorable for the UOR activity enhancement. Meanwhile, Ni(OH)2-NMs have numerous nanoholes, resulting in the mass transportation enhancement. The two factors contribute to the UOR kinetics enhancement at Ni(OH)2-NMs.
Additionally, LSV measurements show that the UOR activity of Ni(OH)2-NMs is much higher than that of commercial Pt black electrocatalysts and RuO2 nanoparticles (Fig. 7a). And, the onset potential of the UOR at Ni(OH)2-NMs is more negative than that at various Ni(OH)2 or NiO nanoparticles and heteroatom doped Ni-based UOR electrocatalysts (Table 1). This comparison confirms the high activity of Ni(OH)2-NMs for the UOR, again. The electrocatalytic activities and stabilities of Ni(OH)2NMs and Ni(OH)2-NPs for the UOR were further characterized by the chronoamperometry test (Fig. 7b). The UOR current at Ni (OH)2-NMs is much higher than that at Ni(OH)2-NPs in the whole measurement time. Thus, chronoamperometry tests also confirm that Ni(OH)2-NMs provide better activity and durability compared to Ni(OH)2-NPs. As shown in the SEM image (Fig. 3b), the Ni(OH)2-NMs have an interconnected 3D structure, which effectively suppresses Ostwald ripening64,65 and endows the Ni(OH)2-NMs with enhanced stability.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text: In summary, we developed a NaBH4 assisted cyanogel hydrolysis method for the direct one-step chemical synthesis of atomically thick Ni(OH)2-NMs. The ultrathin and porous properties of Ni(OH)2-NMs are derived from the particular 2D structural unit in NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel. The as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs possessed an atomic-scale thickness, a big surface area, numerous nanoholes, and substantial edge atoms, which provided highly active electrocatalytic sites and favorable mass transportation. Benefiting from these fascinating structural features, Ni(OH)2-NMs showed a super electrocatalytic performance for the UOR (such as a low onset oxidation potential, high mass activity, small Tafel slope, and good long-term stability), revealing their potential application in direct urea fuel cells and urea-assisted water splitting.

sections.heading: Reagents and chemicals
sections.text: Sodium borohydride (NaBH4), nickel(II) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O) and urea were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Potassium cyanonickelate(II) (K2Ni(CN)4)·xH2O was purchased from Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd (Shanghai, China). Potassium hydroxide (KOH) was obtained from Alfa Aesar (Shanghai, China). RuO2 nanoparticles and Nafion solution (5%) were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corporation (Shanghai, China).

sections.heading: Synthesis of Ni(OH)2 nanomeshes
sections.text:
Firstly, 2 mL of NiCl2·6H2O (1 M) and 2 mL of K2Ni(CN)4 (0.5 M) solutions were mixed at 25 °C. Several hours later, a blue
jelly-like NiCl2–K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel was obtained. Then, 40 mL of NaBH4 (0.13 g mL
−1) solution was poured into the NiCl2– K2Ni(CN)4 cyanogel under strong stirring for 8 h. Finally, Ni(OH)2-NMs were achieved by centrifugation, and dried at 40 °C for 4 h.
For comparison, Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles without nanoholes (termed Ni(OH)2-NPs) were prepared by taking NiCl2 as the NiII source in the same way.

sections.heading: Physical characterization
sections.text: The composition, morphology, crystallographic texture, structure, microstructures, and electronic information of samples were investigated by SEM (SU8220), EDX (Quanta 200), TEM, HR-TEM, SAED, STEM-EDX (TECNAI G2 F20), AFM (Dimension Icon), PXRD (D8 Advance powder X-ray diffractometer), XPS (AXIS ULTRA spectrometer), and nitrogen adsorption desorption analysis (Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 spectrometer).

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: Electrochemical measurements for the UOR were performed on a CHI 660D electrochemical analyzer. A catalyst modified glassy carbon electrode, Pt plate, and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) were used as the working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode, respectively. All tests were implemented at 30 ± 1 °C and all potentials are reported with respect to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The working electrode was prepared according to the previous report.75 The loading capacity of the catalyst on the electrode surface is ca. 0.11 mg cm−2.

sections.heading: Conflicts of interest
sections.text: There are no conflicts to declare.

sections.heading: Acknowledgements
sections.text: This research was sponsored by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (21873061), the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (GK201701003 and 2017TS020), and the National Training Program of Innovation and Entrepreneurship for Undergraduates (CX2018137).

metadata.abstractText: Atomically thick ultrathin nanomeshes (NMs) possessing the inherent advantages of both two-dimensional nanomaterials and porous nanomaterials are attracting increasing interest in catalysis and electrocatalysis. Herein, we report a direct chemical synthesis of atomically thick Ni(OH)2-NMs by a NaBH4 assisted cyanogel hydrolysis method, which overcomes the shortcoming of the post-etching method for NM synthesis. Various physical characterization methods show that the as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs have 1.7 nm thickness, a big surface area, abundant nanoholes, and numerous surface/edge atoms with lowcoordination numbers. The as-synthesized Ni(OH)2-NMs show a better electrocatalytic performance for the urea oxidation reaction than conventional Ni(OH)2 nanoparticles without holes in the alkaline electrolyte, including a lower onset oxidation potential, faster reaction kinetics, and higher mass activity.
metadata.creator: Arbortext Advanced Print Publisher 9.1.520/W Unicode
